title: Cray T3E
text:
The Cray T3E was <a href="Cray%20Research">Cray Research</a>'s second-generation <a href="massively%20parallel">massively parallel</a> supercomputer architecture, launched in late November 1995. The first T3E was installed at the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Supercomputing%20Center">Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center</a> in 1996. Like the previous <a href="Cray%20T3D">Cray T3D</a>, it was a fully distributed memory machine using a 3D <a href="Torus%20interconnect">torus topology interconnect</a>ion network. The T3E initially used the <a href="Digital%20Equipment%20Corporation">DEC</a> <a href="Alpha%2021164">Alpha 21164</a> (EV5) <a href="microprocessor">microprocessor</a> and was designed to scale from 8 to 2,176 "Processing Elements" (PEs). Each PE had between 64 MB and 2 GB of <a href="DRAM">DRAM</a> and a 6-way interconnect router with a payload bandwidth of 480 MB/s in each direction. Unlike many other MPP systems, including the T3D, the T3E was fully self-hosted and ran the <a href="UNICOS">UNICOS</a>/mk <a href="distributed%20operating%20system">distributed operating system</a> with a "GigaRing" I/O subsystem integrated into the torus for network, disk and tape I/O.
The original T3E (retrospectively known as the T3E-600) had a 300 <a href="MHz">MHz</a> processor clock. Later variants, using the faster 21164A (EV56) processor, comprised the T3E-900 (450 MHz), T3E-1200 (600 MHz), T3E-1200E (with improved memory and interconnect performance) and T3E-1350 (675 MHz). The T3E was available in both air-cooled ("AC") and liquid-cooled ("LC") configurations. AC systems were available with 16 to 128 user PEs, LC systems with 64 to 2048 user PEs.
A 1480-processor T3E-1200 was the first supercomputer to achieve a performance of more than 1 <a href="teraflops">teraflops</a> running a <a href="computational%20science">computational science</a> application, in 1998. 
After Cray Research was acquired by <a href="Silicon%20Graphics">Silicon Graphics</a> in February 1996, development of new Alpha-based systems was stopped. While providing the -900, -1200 and -1200E upgrades to the T3E, in the long term Silicon Graphics intended Cray T3E users to migrate to the <a href="Origin%203000">Origin 3000</a>, a <a href="MIPS%20architecture">MIPS</a>-based <a href="distributed%20shared%20memory">distributed shared memory</a> computer, introduced in 2000. However, the T3E continued in production after SGI sold the Cray business the same year.
